Introduction

Personality disorders cause rigidity of thinking (eg, perception of self, others, and situations), feeling (eg, emotional range and reactivity), and behaving (eg, ability to establish/maintain relationships, impulse control).  Characteristics of personality disorders present by early adulthood and are generally stable across time and situations (eg, social, occupational, personal), causing significant functional impairment.



Borderline personality disorder (BPD) involves a persistent pattern of unstable relationships, self-image, and mood, as well as impulsivity.  Patients are highly sensitive and reactive to environmental stress (eg, change in plans), rejection, and separation, which can result in self-injurious behavior and/or suicidality.

Epidemiology



The point prevalence of BPD is estimated to be 1%-2%.  The rate of BPD does not differ significantly between male and female patients; however, the majority of patients in clinical settings are women.  The onset of BPD typically occurs during adolescence and early adulthood.

Pathogenesis



The pathogenesis of BPD is not fully understood but is thought to be a combination of genetic vulnerability and neurobiologic dysfunction (memory/emotion processing) interacting with environmental (parental separation, persistent invalidation) and psychologic (history of trauma, temperament, attachment style) factors.

Clinical presentation



Many patients initially seek care for another psychiatric condition because these are highly comorbid with BPD (eg, mood, substance use, or eating disorders).  Clues that may point toward a diagnosis of BPD include:



  • Devaluation or idealization of provider and treatment recommendations (eg, referring to other providers as useless/horrible; excessive flattering at initial appointment)
  • High emotional reactivity (eg, excessive anger due to provider running a few minutes behind schedule)
  • Multiple phone calls and messages from patient between visits
  • Recurrent suicidality and/or self-injurious behaviors (eg, cutting, burning skin)
  • High use of acute psychiatric and crisis services

Diagnosis



BPD is characterized by a pervasive pattern of relationship, self-image, and emotional instability, as well as impulsivity.  These features begin by early adulthood and include â‰¥5 of any of the following:

Impaired concept of self and others



  • Unstable and intense relationships that alternate between idealization and devaluation (eg, if feeling cared for by another, then that person is great; if feeling rejected/unsupported by another, then that person is horrible)
  • Unstable self-image or sense of self (eg, frequent shifts in interests, values, opinions)
  • Chronic feelings of emptiness (feeling disconnected from self and others)
  • Transient paranoid thoughts (eg, family is conspiring against them) or severe dissociative symptoms (eg, amnesia, feeling detached from body) due to acute stress

Emotional dysregulation



  • Emotional instability due to mood reactivity (eg, intense sadness lasting a few hours in response to acute interpersonal stress)
  • Intense, inappropriate anger (eg, verbal outbursts over minor issues)
  • Frantic efforts to avoid real or perceived abandonment (not including suicidal or self-injurious behaviors) (eg, texting excessively, prematurely ending a supportive relationship)

Behavioral dysregulation



  • Impulsivity in â‰¥2 areas that are potentially self-damaging (eg, substance use, unsafe sex, binge eating, gambling)
  • Recurrent suicidality (eg, attempts, gestures, threats) or self-injurious behaviors

Differential diagnosis



Acute stress responses (eg, physical illness, grief, work-related burnout) can manifest in various ways, including some that overlap with BPD (eg, mood reactivity, intense anger, unstable relationships and sense of self); a diagnosis of BPD is based on traits persisting across a variety of contexts and time (ie, not only in times of crisis).



  • Histrionic personality disorder:  consists of attention-seeking/manipulative behaviors and rapidly changing emotions, although it does not include self-destructive behaviors, intense anger, and an unstable self-image.
  • Dependent personality disorder:  can also be characterized by fears of abandonment; however, these fears result in increasing submissiveness instead of anger, suicidality, and impulsivity.
  • Bipolar disorder:  can also consist of impulsivity, mood lability, and self-destructive behaviors, although these are specific to discrete manic/hypomanic episodes not enduring through time and across multiple contexts.  BPD can occur with bipolar disorder, in which case both diagnoses are given.
  • Major depressive disorder:  can also include suicidality, mood reactivity, and feelings of emptiness, although these symptoms are distinct from baseline and are circumscribed to a depressive episode.  BPD commonly occurs with depression, in which case both diagnoses are given.
  • Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD):  is also characterized by dissociative symptoms, intense anger, and reckless behaviors; however, the symptoms are typically associated with or in response to trauma cues instead of interpersonal stress.  A history of trauma is often present in patients with BPD, which can occur with PTSD.

Management



Disclosing the diagnosis of BPD allows patients to understand their distressing symptoms and behaviors as a defined condition that is also experienced by others.  Providing psychoeducation on the way that BPD develops (eg, genetic, environmental, psychologic factors) and on the availability of effective treatment options is often reassuring to patients.



Patients may have strong emotional responses that are unpredictable and may fluctuate from being overly dependent to making threats toward providers.  Creating a safe and stable clinical environment without judgment or defensiveness establishes trust and builds rapport with patients.  General recommendations for treating patients with BPD include:



  • Validate emotions:  Acknowledge the patient's emotional responses through reflection and summarization, which helps the patient regulate their emotions.
  • Establish clear boundaries:  Discuss appropriate forms of communication, hours of availability, and time when a response can be expected.
  • Take suicidality and self injurious behaviors seriously:  Perform thorough risk assessments and safety planning to determine an appropriate level of care.
  • Collaborate and communicate with other providers:  Create a unified treatment plan and appropriately respond to splitting (alternating between idealization and devaluation; other provider is "all good" or "all bad").


Treatment of BPD consists primarily of psychotherapy.  Multiple types of psychotherapy (eg, dialectical behavior therapy [DBT], transference-focused psychotherapy) are effective at decreasing self-harm, suicidality, and hospitalization.  Specifically, DBT teaches mindfulness techniques to improve distress tolerance and promote emotional and behavioral regulation; this therapy consists of weekly individual and group sessions for a year.



Pharmacotherapy is used as an adjunct to psychotherapy in certain situations (eg, low-dose second-generation antipsychotic for stress-related paranoia, mood stabilizer for emotional lability) if symptoms are severe and unresponsive.

Prognosis



Approximately 10% of patients with BPD die by suicide.  BPD is typically considered a chronic condition, although symptoms tend to improve with age (by mid-40s).  The majority of patients experience sustained remission of symptoms with treatment.  Factors associated with an improved prognosis include lack of comorbid psychiatric conditions or substance use disorders, no history of childhood sexual abuse, and no history of family substance use disorders.

Summary



Borderline personality disorder (
